intro: Wormia quercifolia, commonly known as the oak-leaved wormia, is a unique plant species belonging to the family Apiaceae. It is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves that resemble the foliage of oak trees, giving it its common name. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers arranged in umbels, typical of the carrot family. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodland areas. Due to its delicate structure and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and ecologically significant species.
